text: Applications
ACE 4-1

Plans for a set of stairs for the front of a new community center use the ratio of rise to run of 2 units to 5 units.

a. Recall that the carpenters' guidelines state that:

  • Twice the rise plus the run for each step should be between 24 and 26 inches.
  • The rise plus the run for each step should be between 17 and 19 inches.

If the stairs are built with a rise of 4 inches and a run of 10 inches will they meet the guidelines? If the stairs are built with a rise of 5 inches and a run of 12.5 inches will they meet the guidelines?

b. Sketch a set of stairs that meets the rise-to-run ratio of 2 units to 5 units.

c. Sketch the graph of a line where the y-values change by 2 units for each 5-unit change in the x-values.

d. Write an equation for your line in part (c.).

a. No; the first set of measurements doesn’t meet either guideline. The second set of measurements meets the second guideline, but not the first.

b. See diagram below.

c. Answers will vary. See sample graph below.

d. Answers will vary based on the graphs that students drew for part (c.) and can include any equation of the form y = ⅖x + c where c is any constant number. The equation that corresponds to the graph above is y = ⅖x + 1.
ACE 4-2
a. Find the horizontal distance and the vertical distance between the two labeled points on the graph below.
b. What is the rate of change of the line?

a. horizontal distance: -3;

vertical distance: 3

b. Slope = (vertical change/horizontal change) = (3/-3) = -1
ACE 4-3

Damon never manages to make his allowance last for a whole week, so he borrows money from his sister. Suppose Damon borrows 50 cents every week.

a. Write an equation for the amount of money m Damon owes his sister after n weeks.

b. What is the slope of the graph of the equation from part (a.)?

c. If he continues borrowing money at this rate, when will Damon owe his sister more than $5?

a. m = 0.50n Here, n is in dollars (If n is in cents, the equation becomes m = 50n.)

b. slope = 0.50

c. Damon will owe his sister more than $5 when n > 10 weeks.
ACE 4-4

Robert is installing a patio in his backyard. At 2:00 P.M., he has 120 stones laid in the ground. At 3:30 P.M., he has 180 stones in the ground. His design for the patio says he needs 400 stones total.

a. When would you predict he will be done?

b. What is a reasonable estimate for when he started?

c. If you wanted to know how many stones he would have in the ground at any time, what would be most helpful to you: an equation, a graph, or a table? Explain.

a. Robert is laying 60 stones in 90 minutes, which is 2 stones every 3 minutes or 40 stones an hour. He has 220 stones left, so it should take about 220 ÷ 40 = 5.5 hours at the same rate. So, he should finish at about 9:00 p.m.

b. Because he has 120 stones laid at 2:00 P.M., he is 3 hours into the work, so he would have started at about 11:00 A.M.

c. Answers will vary. Students may say that an equation will allow for a more precise answer but that graphs and tables allow for more visual inspection and estimation.
ACE 4-5

At noon, the temperature is 30 degrees F. For the next several hours, the temperature falls by an average of 3 degrees F an hour.

a. Write an equation for the temperature T, n hours after noon.

b. What is the y-intercept of the line the equation represents? What does the y-intercept tell you about this situation?

c. What is the slope of the line the equation represents? What does the slope tell you about this situation?

a. T = 30 – 3n

b. y-intercept = 30; the y-intercept gives the starting temperature after 0 hours.

c. Slope = 3; the slope tells you the rate of change (decrease) in temperature for each hour.
ACE 4-6

Rachel currently has $65 in a savings account and plans to deposit $1.50 each week to keep building it. Her sister Laura doesn’t have a savings account yet, but plans to start one by depositing $2.50 each week.

a. Laura sets a goal to follow her savings plan for 26 weeks, because then she will have as much money in her savings account as her sister. Will Laura’s plan work? Why or why not?

b. Is it possible for Laura’s savings account to grow larger than Rachel’s? If so, when will this happen?

a. Laura’s plan will not work. After 26 weeks she will have $65 saved, but Rachel will continue to save during that time, too. So, Rachel will have $65 + $1.50(26) = $104.

b. Laura’s savings account will grow larger than Rachel’s after 65 weeks. You can do this by finding when 2.50n > 65 + 1.50n.
ACE 4-7

Seven possible descriptions of lines are listed below.

i. positive slope

ii. negative slope

iii. y-intercept equals 0

iv. passes through the point (1, 2)

v. slope of zero

vi. positive y-intercept

vii. negative y-intercept

For each equation, list all of the descriptions i–vii that describe the graph of that equation.

a. y = 2x

b. y = 3−3x

c. y = 2x + 3

d. y = 5x−3

e. y = 2

a. i, iii, iv

b. ii, vi

c. i, vi

d. i, iv, vii

e. iv, v, vi
ACE 4-8

The tables represent linear relationships.

  • Give the slope and the y-intercept of the graph of each relationship.
  • Then match each of the following equations with the appropriate table.

• Table A; Equation 2; slope = 2; y-intercept = 0
  • Table B; Equation 5; slope = 1; y-intercept = 3.5
  • Table C; Equation 4; slope = 2; y-intercept can be found by “counting back” in the table: (0, –1)
  • Table D; Equation 1; slope = –2; y-intercept = 5;
  • Table E; Equation 3; slope = –3; y-intercept can be found by “counting back” in the table: (0, –5);
ACE 4-9

a. Find the slope of the line represented by each equation\

  • y = x−1
  • y = -2x + 3

b. Make a table of x- and y-values for each equation How is the slope related to the table entries?

a. Slope = 1; Slope = -2

b. The slope is the change in the y-values compared to the change in the x-values between two points in the table. As the x-values go up by 1, the y-values go up by 1. So, the slope is 1.
The slope is the change in the y-values compared to the change in the x-values between two points in the table. As the x-values go up by 1, the y-values go down by 2. So, the slope -2.
ACE 4-10

For each pair of points do the following:

  • Plot the points on a coordinate grid and draw a line through them.
  • Find the slope of the line.
  • Find the y-intercept of the line. Explain how you found the y-intercept.
  • Use your answers from parts (b.) and (c.) to write an equation for the line.
  • Find one more point that lies on the line.

a. (0, 0) and (3, 3)

b. (-1,1) and (3, -3)

c. (0, −5) and (−2, −3)

d. (3, 6) and (5, 6)

a. slope = 1

y-intercept = 0; the y-intercept is where the graph crosses the y-axis, so you could look at the graph.

y = x

Possible answers: (6, 6), (–1, –1)

b. slope = –1

y-intercept = 0; the y-intercept is where the graph crosses the y-axis, so you could look at the graph.

y = –x

Possible answers: (0, 0), (–3, 3)

c. slope = –1

y-intercept = –5; the y-intercept is where the graph crosses the y-axis, so you could look at the graph

y = –x – 5

Possible answers: (1, –6), (–1, –4)

d. slope = 0

y-intercept = 6; the y-intercept is where the graph crosses the y-axis, so you could look at the graph.

y = 6

Possible answers: (1, 6), (2, 6)
ACE 4-11
Determine which of the linear relationships A–K fit the descriptions given below.

i. The line corresponding to this relationship has positive slope.

ii. The line corresponding to this relationship has a slope of -2

iii. The line corresponding to this relationship has a slope of 0.

iv. Matches the equation y = x – 1

v. Matches the equation y = -2

vi. Matches the equation y = 1/4x

i. B, E, and J

ii. A, F, and K

iii. C, D, G, and H

iv. graph B

v. graph D

vi. graph E
Connections
ACE 4-12
Some hills have signs indicating their steepness, or slope. Here are some examples:
On a coordinate grid, sketch hills with each of these slopes.

Possible Graphs below.

17%: y = -0.17x

8%: y = 0.08x
ACE 4-13
Use the graph below to answer each question.

a. Are any of the rectangles in the picture above similar? If so, tell which rectangles, and explain why they are similar.

b. Find the slope of the diagonal line. How is it related to the similar rectangles?

c. Which of these rectangles belong to the set of rectangles in the graph? Explain.

a. Yes; the ratios of their sides are all 2 : 3, since from smaller to larger the ratios are 2 : 3, 4 : 6, 6 : 9, 8 : 12, which all are equivalent to 2 : 3.

b. ⅔ ; the slope of the diagonal line is ⅔ since the ratio of rise to run is 2 to 3. The slope is related to the similar rectangles because the ratio of the adjacent sides for each rectangle is the same as the ratio of rise to run, which is the slope.

c. Neither rectangle is in the set, because neither has a slope of ⅔. However, the first is similar to those shown in the graph; it is just oriented differently.
ACE 4-14
The graph below shows the height of a rocket from 10 seconds before liftoff through 7 seconds after liftoff.

a. Describe the relationship between the height of the rocket and time.

b. What is the slope for the part of the graph that is a straight line? What does this slope represent in this situation?

a. Before liftoff, the rocket is stationary (it is on the launch pad awaiting ignition). At time = 0, the engines are ignited. It appears that the rocket rises rapidly in the first 2 seconds, and then gradually tapers off.

b. Before liftoff, the slope is 0. The rate of increase in altitude during this time (while the rocket is stationary) is 0.
ACE 4-15

Solve each equation. Check your answers.

a. 2(x + 5) = 18

b. 2(x + 5) = x − 8

c. 2(x + 5) = x

d. 2(x + 5) = −15

Which equation has a graph that contains the point (−2, 7)?

A. y = 4x + 1

B. y = −x + 5

C. y = 3x−11

D. y = −3x + 11
ACE 4-17
Find a value of n that will make each statement true.
e. Write an equation for a line whose slope is -4/6.

a. n = 15

b. n = 15

c. n = –2

d. n = 72

e. Answers will vary. Sample answer: y = –(4/6)x + 2
ACE 4-18
Solve each equation or inequality and check your answers.
ACE 4-19

Use properties of equality and numbers to solve each equation for x. Check your answers.

a. 3 + 6x = 4x + 9

b. 6x + 3 = 4x + 9

c. 6x−3 = 4x + 9

d. 3−6x = 4x + 9
ACE 4-20

Find a value of n that will make each statement true.

a. of 90 is n.

b. 20% of n is 80.

c. n% of 50 is 5.

a. n = 13.5

b. n = 400

c. n = 10
Extensions
ACE 4-21

Jada's track team decides to convert their running rates from miles per hour to kilometers per hour (l mile ≈ 1.6 kilometers).

a. Which method would you use to help the team do their converting: graph, table, or equation? Explain why you chose your method.

b. One of Jada's teammates said that she could write an equation for her spreadsheet program that could convert any team member's running rate from miles per hour to kilometers per hour. Write an equation that each member could use for this conversion.

a. Answers will vary. Possible answer: A table because the information would be easy to read.

b. kilometers = 1.6 х miles; y = 1.6x
ACE 4-22
Three students build the following pattern using the least number of toothpicks possible. For example, Figure 2 uses 5 toothpicks. Suppose that this pattern continues beyond Figure 3.

a. The students are trying to figure out the perimeter of Figure 6 without building it. For each student's method, tell whether you agree or disagree. If you agree, explain why. If you disagree, describe what is incorrect about the student's reasoning.
b. The students want to figure out a way to calculate how many toothpicks T they would need to build any figure number F. Which students wrote correct equations? Explain.

a. Juan’s method is correct; the perimeter increases by 1 each time. Natalie makes a common mistake. To convince students that she is incorrect, you should be able to apply her reasoning from Figure 1 to Figure 3 by tripling the perimeter of Figure 1. But this would mean that Figure 3 has a perimeter of 9, which we can see is not true. Steven’s method does not work because there are segments that are no longer part of the perimeter when another triangle is added on to the existing figure.

b. All three students are correct in their reasoning and their equations. All the expressions are equivalent. Students may justify each equation separately using the picture, or, if they recognize that the expressions are equivalent, they may justify one from the diagram and then say that the others are true by transforming one expression into a different, equivalent one.
ACE 4-23

On a March flight from Boston to Detroit, a monitor displayed the altitude and the outside air temperature. Two passengers that were on that flight tried to find a formula for temperature t in degrees Fahrenheit at an altitude of a feet above sea level. One passenger said the formula was t = 46−0.003a, and the other said it was t = 46 + 0.003a.

a. Which formula makes more sense to you? Why?

b. The Detroit Metropolitan Airport is 620 feet above sea level. Use the formula you chose in part (a.) to find the temperature at the airport on that day.

c. Does the temperature you found in part (b.) seem reasonable? Why or why not?

a. Temperature should decrease as altitude increases, so t = 46 – 0.003a makes more sense.

b. t = 46 – 0.003(620) = 44.14°F

c. Yes; A temperature of 44°F makes sense for Detroit in March.
ACE 4-24

Remy is looking at two different electronic game subscriptions. In the first subscription plan, the company sends 6 new games each month for $20. In the second subscription plan, the company sends 2 games the first month, and then doubles the number of comic books that they send you each month after that, for $30 each month. Remy makes a table of how large his game collection will be each month for both subscription plans:

tiles.title: Total Number of Comic Books Owned

text: Remy decides to choose Plan 1, because it is less expensive and he will get more games. Do you agree with Remy? Why or why not?
Remy is correct for the first few months. Plan 2 is doubling each month. So, the number of magazines will grow much faster than just adding 6 each month.

tiles.title: Total Number of Comic Books Owned
